awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Advancing Robust Control and State Estimation of Converter-Based Power Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Future power grids, the nation’s most critical infrastructure, will be extremely difficult to manage due to large-scale integration of renewable energy resources. The strategy proposed in this project is aided by new grid technologies (converter-based assets in wind/solar farms and high-frequency sensing devices) that are developed and deployed to allow new real-time control-theoretic algorithms to be implemented with little overhead---while guaranteeing grid stability and resilience. The literature in this area had addressed various scientific research questions, but mostly adopted simplified models that cannot adequately capture the real-time operation of future grids. This project addresses this science gap by developing a new set of real-time algorithms, leading to a more robust operation of future power grids characterized with high penetration of renewable energy resources. These control algorithms can be implemented by grid operators throughout the nation. The project will also include: a) hosting an outreach workshop on renewable energy systems for a low-income, minority-majority, and female-only high school in San Antonio; b) organizing a technical industry workshop that showcases the created algorithms in the state of Iowa; c) disseminating the created scientific methods within the curricula at the University of Texas at San Antonio and Iowa State University.


This project aims at modernizing grid control methods which has traditionally relied on linear systems theory. In particular, the control-theoretic literature addressed a plethora of grid challenges with a focus on linearized, differential equation models whereby algebraic constraints (i.e., power flows) are eliminated. This is in contrast with the more realistic, complex nonlinear differential algebraic equation (NDAE) models. Linearizing grid models around operating points and eliminating algebraic constraints have proven to be a reliable strategy---a trade-off between complexity and tractability. Yet as grids are increasingly pushed to their limits via intermittent renewables, their physical states risk escaping operating regions due to a poor prediction of wind or solar. In lieu of linear differential equation models, control of NDAEs is highly beneficial for grids that are characterized by highly uncertain renewables. This guarantees grid stability for larger operating conditions. Given the limitations of present power system models and the lack of theoretical foundations for control and dynamic state estimation of grid NDAEs, this project will: 1) create a physically representative NDAE model of a power system with a mix of conventional machines and a variety of converter-based technologies; 2) investigate a general theory of dynamic state estimation and robust feedback control algorithms that consider the uncertain nature of power grids modeled via higher-order NDAEs; 3) obtain computationally tractable routines that can be implemented in control centers of power grids. The created theoretical foundations have applications in wide area control, converter-based control, centralized and decentralized and robust dynamic state estimation. This research is critical to guarantee acceptable performance of modern and future power systems and will lead to advancing the state-of-the-art of grid control studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project has:

(i)  Developed a positive-sequence model of a power converter with grid-forming controls. The converter can be powered by either solar arrays, wind turbines, or battery energy storage. The model of the grid-forming converter is suitable to study the fault ride-through capability of these new class of converter-based resources. The model was coupled to mathematical representations of conventional synchronous machines as well as transmission lines and loads in the positive-sequence domain which resulted in a set of differential algebraic equations. The grid-forming technology was also tested in the electromagnetic transient domain while studying fault-induced delayed voltage recovery events.

(ii) Engineered an active protection systems to prevent dc-link voltage collapse of grid-forming units that are powered by solar photovoltaic arrays which in turn depend on the variability of solar irradiance. It was showcased that grid-forming photovoltaic power plants can lose synchronism during variations of solar irradiance because it can cause dc-link voltage collapse. The protection interfaces with the classical droop-control law for grid-forming operation by automatically reducing the amount of power transfered by the converter from the dc-link into the ac power grid. It was was engineered a method to estimate solar irradiance using: an abstract PV array model, PV current, and dc-link voltage. These controls loops yielded a feedback control algorithm that makes the grid-forming inverter robust to uncertain solar irradiance disturbances.

(iii) Set forth a method to propagate initial-condition uncertainties through nonlinear dynamics of power systems with GFM resources. The method forwards initial condition uncertainties (modeled as multivariate polynomial vectors) in time via an explicit 5th-order Runge-Kutta integration rule.  Further, it was also engineered a grid-forming power plant model that is steered by differentiable two-axis anti-windup proportional-integral (PI) regulators. The model is suitable to propagate initial-condition uncertainties even when current saturation occurs. This contribution is supplemented with an algorithm to expedite the truncated multiplication of multivariate polynomials by mapping  the coefficients of two multiplicand polynomials of a particular degree into the coefficients of a resulting one of the same degree. Further, it was developed a  method to ascertain stability from the calculated polynomial vectors based on contraction theory. The latter approach is significant for future power system operators because the absence of rotors in grid-forming power plants challenges classical transient stability approaches.

(iv) Trained a PhD student as well as developed and delivered a short course to industry with the support of the Electric Power Research Center at Iowa State University. The objective of the course was to control and EMT simulate primary energy resources for grid-forming generation resources.The considered primary energy resources were solar arrays, wind turbines, and battery energy storage.

Overall, the outcomes of this project are significant to support the U.S. strategies to achieve zero emissions by year 2050 and to address grid-forming technical concerns raised by reliability organizations.
